com.topcoder.timetracker.common
Class TimeTrackerBean

java.lang.Object
  com.topcoder.timetracker.common.TimeTrackerBean
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable
Direct Known Subclasses:
PaymentTerm
public abstract class TimeTrackerBean
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable

This is a bean base class used to represent all entities of the Time Tracker Application, which it persisted into the database. It contains all the properties which are common to these entities (id, creation date, modification date, creation user, modification user and changed flag). It is also Serializable to support network transfer, and state persistence.

Thread Safety: This class is mutable, and not thread-safe. Multiple threads are advised to work with their own bean instance.

Version:
3.1
Author:
TCSDESIGNER, TCSDEVELOPER
See Also:
Serialized Form

Constructor Detail

protected TimeTrackerBean()

Default constructor take no-arg to follow the JavaBeans conventions.

Method Detail

getCreationDate

public java.util.Date getCreationDate()

Retrieves the date when this entity was initially defined within the Time Tracker data store.

Note:

  • The returned value may be null when this is a blank bean for initial data population, but it will always be non-null if this bean is populated from the data store.
  • Changes on the returned Date object will not affect the inner state of this bean.

Returns:
the date when this entity was initially defined within the Time Tracker data store.

setCreationDate

public void setCreationDate(java.util.Date creationDate)

Sets the date when this entity was initially defined within the Time Tracker data store.

Note: No validation is performed here against the argument, so indeed users can set any values(even invalid). But for the Time Tracker Common component:

  • If you are planning to call SimpleCommonManager.addPaymentTerm(PaymentTerm) with this bean, calling this method will not make any sense. The value you set will always be replaced by current date.
  • If you are planning to call SimpleCommonManager.updatePaymentTerm(PaymentTerm) with this bean, you must ensure that you call this method and set a non-null value, otherwise IllegalArgumentException will be raised.
  • If you are not planning to use SimpleCommonManager but instead use DatabasePaymentTermDAO to add/update PaymentTerm directly, you must ensure that you call this method and set a non-null value, otherwise IllegalArgumentException will be raised.

Changes on the passed Date object will not affect the inner state of this bean.

Parameters:
creationDate - the date when this entity was initially defined within the Time Tracker data store.

getModificationDate

public java.util.Date getModificationDate()

Retrieves the date when any of the fields of this entity was modified within Time Tracker data store.

Note:

  • The returned value may be null when this is a blank bean for initial data population, but it will always be non-null if this bean is populated from the data store.
  • Changes on the returned Date object will not affect the inner state of this bean.

Returns:
the date when any of the fields of this entity was modified within Time Tracker data store.

setModificationDate

public void setModificationDate(java.util.Date modificationDate)

Sets the date when any of the fields of this entity was modified within Time Tracker data store.

Recommendation: It is not recommended for this method to be called by normal code. This method is likely to be called only by the SimpleCommonManager class, and isn't something that the user of this component should concern themselves with.

Note: No validation is performed here against the argument, so indeed users can set any values(even invalid). But for the Time Tracker Common component:

  • If you are planning to call SimpleCommonManager.addPaymentTerm(PaymentTerm) or SimpleCommonManager.updatePaymentTerm(PaymentTerm) with this bean, calling this method will not make any sense. The value you set will always be replaced by current date.
  • If you are not planning to use SimpleCommonManager but instead use DatabasePaymentTermDAO to add/update PaymentTerm directly, you must ensure that you call this method and set a non-null value, otherwise IllegalArgumentException will be raised.

Changes on the passed Date object will not affect the inner state of this bean.

Parameters:
modificationDate - the date when any of the fields of this entity was modified within Time Tracker data store.

getCreationUser

public java.lang.String getCreationUser()

Retrieves the user that initially defined this entity within the Time Tracker data store.

Note: The returned value may be null this is a blank bean for initial data population, but it will always be non-null, non-empty and with length not greater than 64 if this bean is populated from the data store.

Returns:
the user that initially defined this entity within the Time Tracker data store.

setCreationUser

public void setCreationUser(java.lang.String creationUser)

Sets the user that initially defined this entity within the Time Tracker data store.

Note: No validation is performed here against the argument, so indeed users can set any values(even invalid). But for the Time Tracker Common component, if you are planning to use SimpleCommonManager or DatabasePaymentTermDAO to add/update PaymentTerm, you must ensure that you call this method and set a non-null, non-empty(trimmed) string value with length not greater than 64, otherwise IllegalArgumentException will be raised.

Parameters:
creationUser - the user that initially defined this entity within the Time Tracker data store.

getModificationUser

public java.lang.String getModificationUser()

Retrieves the user that most recently modified this entity within the Time Tracker data store.

Note: The returned value may be null when this is a blank bean for initial data population, but it will always be non-null, non-empty and with length not greater than 64 if this bean is populated from the data store.

Returns:
the user that most recently modified this entity within the Time Tracker data store.

setModificationUser

public void setModificationUser(java.lang.String modificationUser)

Sets the user that most recently modified this entity within the Time Tracker data store.

Note: No validation is performed here against the argument, so indeed users can set any values(even invalid). But for the Time Tracker Common component:

  • If you are planning to call SimpleCommonManager.addPaymentTerm(PaymentTerm) with this bean, and if you set a null modification user or even do not call this method, then the modification user will be replaced by creation user. If you do call this method and set a non-null modification user, please ensure it is also non-empty(trimmed) and with length not greater than 64, otherwise IllegalArgumentException will be raised.
  • If you are planning to call SimpleCommonManager.updatePaymentTerm(PaymentTerm) with this bean, you must ensure that you call this method and set a non-null, non-empty(trimmed) string value with length not greater than 64, otherwise IllegalArgumentException will be raised.
  • If you are not planning to use SimpleCommonManager but instead use DatabasePaymentTermDAO to add/update PaymentTerm directly, you must ensure that you call this method and set a non-null, non-empty(trimmed) string value with length not greater than 64, otherwise IllegalArgumentException will be raised.

Parameters:
modificationUser - the user that most recently modified this entity within the Time Tracker data store.

getId

public long getId()

Retrieves the unique identifier that distinguishes each entity within the Time Tracker application.

Note: The returned value will be -1 when this is a blank bean for initial data population, but it will always be positive if this bean is populated from the data store.

Returns:
the unique identifier that distinguishes each entity within the Time Tracker application

setId

public void setId(long id)

Sets the unique identifier that distinguishes each entity within the Time Tracker application.

Note: No validation is performed here against the argument, so indeed users can set any values(even invalid). But for the Time Tracker Common component:

  • If you are planning to use SimpleCommonManager or DatabasePaymentTermDAO to add PaymentTerm, calling this method will not make any sense. The value you set will always be replaced by an id auto generated by IDGenerator. Also you should not add a duplicate PaymentTerm by setting a duplicate unique identifier.
  • If you are planning to use SimpleCommonManager or DatabasePaymentTermDAO to update PaymentTerm, you must ensure that you call this method and set a positive value, otherwise IllegalArgumentException will be raised. Also you should not update a non-exist PaymentTerm by setting a non-exist unique identifier.

Parameters:
id - the unique identifier that distinguishes each entity within the Time Tracker application

isChanged

public boolean isChanged()

Checks whether any of the additional bean data has changed.

Note: For the Time Tracker Common component, the SimpleCommonManager.updatePaymentTerm(PaymentTerm) will check the changed status to determine whether to update or not.

Returns:
whether any of the additional bean data has changed.

setChanged

public void setChanged(boolean changed)

Generally this method will called within the setters of some bean class which extends this abstract bean to indicate that whether any of the additional data has been changed.

Note: For the Time Tracker Common component,

  • The SimpleCommonManager.addPaymentTerm(PaymentTerm) will set the changed status to false after success adding.
  • The SimpleCommonManager.updatePaymentTerm(PaymentTerm) will set the changed status to false after success updating.
  • All the retrieve methods of SimpleCommonManager will set the changed status to false after success retrieving.

Parameters:
changed - true If the bean is changed and need be updated; false otherwise.
See Also:
SimpleCommonManager.updatePaymentTerm(PaymentTerm)

equals

public boolean equals(java.lang.Object obj)

Indicates whether this bean is equal to the specified object.

They are considered equal if the other object is also type of TimeTrackerBean and they have identical ids.

If the given object is null, false is returned.

Parameters:
obj - The other object to compare to.
Returns:
True if the 2 objects are equal. False if the other object is null or is not considered equal.

hashCode

public int hashCode()

Returns the hash code based on the id of this bean. The calculation is same as the Long.hashCode().

Returns:
The hash code based on the id of this bean.
